PURPOSE   The purpose of this document is to outline the execution plan for the activities   allowed under the Limited Notice to Proceed (LNTP) for the Gulf MTP LNG   Receiving Terminal Project. The LNTP scope is in line with Exhibit Q of the EPCC   Contract and focusing on the early-stage Engineering, Procurement and   Construction works which are related to the Project‚Äôs Critical Path.      2. PROJECT KICK-OFF AND ORGANIZATION   2.1. Task Force Office at Contractor‚Äôs Head Office (Korea)   Contractor will establish a dedicated Task Force Office at its Head Office in Korea.   This office will function as the center of all coordination for all LNTP related   engineering, procurement and planning activities.   To facilitate fast and efficient decision making, Owner‚Äôs representatives presence is   required at the Task Force Office, especially during the LNTP period. This will enable   realtime clarification and alignment on technical and design issues, timely review   and approval of Project deliverables, etc.      2.2. Kick Off Meeting with Owner   Kick Off Meeting shall be held within one (1) month from the effective date of LNTP.   The KOM will be conducted at Contractor‚Äôs Task Force Office and will enable to   achieve the objectives of the KOM such as review of the Project Scope of Work,   review of Project schedule and LNTP plan, Role and Responsibilities,   communication protocol, interface plan, risk management of LNTP activities, set up   of information management systems, and overall project execution plan and   organization.      2.3. Project Administrative Requirements   1) Insurances in Part 2 of Exhibit P of the Contract as ‚ÄúContractor Furnished   Insurance‚Äù insuring at all times from Limited Notice to Proceed and during the   required period. Owner shall provide ‚ÄúOwner Furnished Insurance‚Äù upon   commencement of LNTP.    2) Preparation of Notice to Proceed Condition Precedent    One of the Contractor‚Äôs key responsibilities during the LNTP period is to   proactively monitor, coordinate, and fulfill the Conditions Precedent (CP) as   specified in the EPCC Contract.            PMC Doc. Title LNTP Execution Plan   Doc. No. GMTP-EPCC-GE-XXX-R0   Rev. No. R0   Page  5 of 8                    3. ENGINEERING   3.1. FEED Verification   This is for the Contractor‚Äôs verification to ensure that Project specification and   requirements of the Owner for Phase I facilities, which is the Contractor‚Äôs scope of   work, are satisfied in terms of Terminal capacity and performance.   1) The purpose of FEED verification is to identify and resolve potential issues at an   early stage of the project, ensuring that a finalized design is in place prior to the   start of detailed engineering. This approach is intended to prevent any adverse   impacts on the subsequent phases of the project.   By reviewing the FEED design against the required capacity and performance,   and addressing any discrepancies or design concerns, improvements or   changes are required that lead to a more reasonable, optimized, safe and   practical solution.   These enhancements are expected to provide clear benefits to the Owner,   particularly in terms of operability and maintainability. The decisions and   resolution presented in this report will support the smooth and timely   progression of the detailed engineering phase.   2) In this FEED Verification, the Scope of Work is based on the FEED documents   provided in Exhibit A, Sections II and III. The scope includes both Process and   Non-Process facilities and systems, including all relevant design aspects   required to verify compliance with the project‚Äôs capacity, performance, and   safety requirements.   The verification work includes the review and assessment of:   ¬∑ PFDs & P&IDs   ¬∑ Equipment sizing and specifications   ¬∑ Utility systems and integration   ¬∑ Layout of process and non-process areas   ¬∑ Identification of any inconsistencies, design gaps, or potential   improvements   ¬∑ Operability and future tie-in requirements   This scope aims to ensure that the FEED package forms a reliable basis for   detailed engineering, construction, and operation, minimizing risks of late-stage   design changes and ensuring alignment with the Owner‚Äôs expectations.
